Getting retrenched is probably the furthest thing from the mind of a young worker starting out in their career.

But for 28-year-old Asaad Fazah, it became a harsh reality in May last year.

But after a 5-month job hunt, and countless resumes and online courses, he got good news.

With the SGUnited Mid-Career Pathways programme, he was able to enrol in a traineeship, and pick up new skills in an industry he had no prior background in.

Watch his journey at go.gov.sg/resetplaylist

How does a vaccine protect you from the COVID-19 virus?  Why do we need it? ğŸ¤” 

Vaccines help our bodies produce antibodies to the virus - there are different methods of doing so, such as using a weakened or inactive virus ğŸ¦ , or the newer mRNA technology ğŸ”¬. Want to find out more? Read on at go.gov.sg/govsg-vaccines1-ig (link in bio!)

ğŸ›¬ The first shipment of COVID-19 vaccines arrived in Singapore on 21 December.

The Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine was transported on Singapore Airlines flight SQ7979, which departed on Sunday 20 December from Brussels, and landed at Singapore Changi Airport at 7.36pm on Monday.

The vaccines were packed in thermal shipper boxes filled with dry ice designed to keep the vials at -70 degree Celsius.

Upon arrival, ground handler SATS moved the vaccines to its cold chain facility. They were then loaded onto a refrigerated truck that would send them to an external storage facility with capabilities to handle ultra-cold storage at about -80 degree Celsius.

Staff and logistics partners have been trained up to WHO standards to be able to handle the cargo safely.

For more information on how Singapore secured access to the vaccines, go to go.gov.sg/vaccinearrival-sg-ig (link in bio)

Photos: Ministry of Communications and Information (MCI)

â€œVolunteering is natural to me. Whenever I see an opportunity for me to help, I will always ask if I can be part of the team. I want to help.â€

How did he get started, and what motivates him to continue engineering for the good of the community?

Together with her brother Adriel, 12, she has sewn some 300 masks for lower-income families, during the Circuit Breaker period.

â€œIt doesnâ€™t hurt to make the first move to help those in needâ€, Beatrice says. She hopes that more young people will step out of their comfort zones and give back to society.

As Singapore tackles the economic challenges brought about by COVID-19, let us be the generation that bounces back even stronger as one economy, one society and one nation. 
We can continue to create a brighter future for our children and their children to come.

#SGUnited #SGTogether

We have been fighting against the COVID-19 pandemic and coping with its economic impact, with the belief that we will emerge stronger together. 
Check out more stories of how Singaporeans are tackling the challenges they face with resilience and grit.

Visit talkofthetown.gov.sg to read their stories.

Phase Two of re-opening is here, but please, be steady Singapore! ğŸ’ª

Here are 7 ways you can continue to protect yourself and your loved ones, and keep COVID-19 at bay.

Watch the films and be inspired by fellow Singaporeans who are standing strong in the face of the adversity @ www.go.gov.sg/StrongerTogetherSG

From 17 June 2359 hours, all incoming travellers will need to be tested for COVID-19, while travellers from some countries/regions will no longer need to serve their Stay-Home Notice (SHN) at dedicated SHN facilities. Travellers will need to bear these costs, as part of the cost of travel in a COVID-19 world.
Singapore is moving to Phase 2 of re-opening on 18 June 2359hrs. More activities will resume, with safe management measure in place.

COVID-19 will not change who we are as a nation and our resolve to rise above challenges.

Singapore can emerge stronger from the COVID-19 crisis, said Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong in his national broadcast on 7 June.
